net.acperience.kerberos

Class KerberosAuth

  • java.lang.Object
    • net.acperience.kerberos.KerberosAuth
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    javax.security.auth.callback.CallbackHandler
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    MusicKerberos

    public abstract class KerberosAuth
extends java.lang.Object
implements javax.security.auth.callback.CallbackHandler
    An abstract wrapper class to perform Kerberos authentication using Java. To use this class, you must first perform some configuration as described at this page.

    An implementing class must implement the abstract methods described
    • getPersistentSubject(): Used to see if a subject has been authenticated
    • storePersistentSubject(javax.security.auth.Subject): Used to store a persistent subject upon successful login
    • destroyPersistentSubject(): Destroy a persistent subject upon logout
    • getUsername(): Used to get a username for authentication
    • getPassword(): Used to get a password for authentication
    After constructing the object, to populate the necessary fields, call authenticate()
    Author:
    Lawliet
    See Also:
    Link for documentation, MusicKerberos} for an example implementation

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      KerberosAuth(java.lang.String name)
      Default constructor to do no configuration changes.
      KerberosAuth(java.lang.String name, java.lang.String authLoginConfig)
      An overloaded constructor to provide a path to a JAAS Login configuration file along with the name of the LoginModule.
      KerberosAuth(java.lang.String name, java.lang.String authLoginConfig, java.lang.String krb5Config)
      An overloaded constructor to provide a path to a JAAS Login Configuration file, name of LoginModule and a path to a Kerberos Configuration file.
      KerberosAuth(java.lang.String name, java.lang.String authLoginConfig, java.lang.String krbRealm, java.lang.String krbKdc)
      An overloaded consturctor to provide a LoginModule name, a path to a JAAS configuration file along with the Kerberos realm and Kerberos Key distribution center.

             throws javax.security.auth.login.LoginException,
                    java.lang.SecurityException
        Default constructor to do no configuration changes. Java will attempt to authenticate based on default settings.
        Parameters:
        name - Name of the LoginModule to use.
        Throws:
        javax.security.auth.login.LoginException
        java.lang.SecurityException
        See Also:
        Java Documentation

        krb5Config - Path to a Kerberos Authentication file

        java.lang.SecurityException

      • handle

        public void handle(javax.security.auth.callback.Callback[] callbacks)
            throws java.io.IOException,
                   javax.security.auth.callback.UnsupportedCallbackException
        Handle login callbacks - implemented as required by CallbackHandler This is used by Java's Kerberos Login module. Do not call this normally.
        Specified by:
        handle in interface javax.security.auth.callback.CallbackHandler
        Parameters:
        callbacks - The Callback object provided by Java's Login module.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException
        javax.security.auth.callback.UnsupportedCallbackException

      • isAuthenticated

        public boolean isAuthenticated()
        Check if we have a subject authenticated. Remember to call authenticate() first to populate the necessary data in the object.
        Returns:
        whether a user has been authenticated

      • authenticate

        public void authenticate(boolean doLogin)
                  throws javax.security.auth.login.LoginException
        Authenticates and populates the subject field of the class

        Method will first attempt to load a persistent subject.
        Failing that, will attempt to load a subject from the LoginContext
        If that fails, depending on whether doLogin is set to true or not, will perform a login
        Parameters:
        doLogin - Set to true to perform a login
        Throws:
        javax.security.auth.login.LoginException

      • authenticate

        public void authenticate()
                  throws javax.security.auth.login.LoginException,
                         java.lang.SecurityException
        Convenience method to authenticate(boolean) with the parameter set to true.
        Authenticates and populates the subject field of the class

        Method will first attempt to load a persistent subject.
        Failing that, will attempt to load a subject from the LoginContext
        If that fails, method will perform a login
        Throws:
        javax.security.auth.login.LoginException
        java.lang.SecurityException

      • login

        public void login()
           throws javax.security.auth.login.LoginException
        Performs a login. Method will populate the data via a call to authenticate() after login is complete.
        Throws:
        javax.security.auth.login.LoginException

      • logout

        public void logout()
            throws javax.security.auth.login.LoginException
        Performs a logout. Method will populate the data via a call to authenticate() after login is complete.
        Throws:
        javax.security.auth.login.LoginException

      • getPersistentSubject

        protected abstract javax.security.auth.Subject getPersistentSubject()
        Override this method to allow the class to retrieve any stored authenticated subjects.
        If no one has been authenticated, return NULL and the class will attempt to authenticate
        If not using persistent subjects, just override an empty method.
        Returns:
        The subject stored in some persistent storage or NULL if none

      • storePersistentSubject

        protected abstract void storePersistentSubject(javax.security.auth.Subject subject)
        Store a persistent subject. Called after a successful login attempt.
        If not storing, just override an empty method

      • destroyPersistentSubject

        protected abstract void destroyPersistentSubject()
        Destroys a persistent subject upon successful logout attempt.
        If not using persistent subject, override an empty method.

      • getUsername

        protected abstract java.lang.String getUsername()
        Override this method to allow the class to get a username for authentication purposes if necessary
        Returns:
        Username for authentication

      • getPassword

        protected abstract java.lang.String getPassword()
        Override this method to allow the class to get a password for authentication purposes if necessary
        Returns:
        Password for authentication
